You know... a great example to illustrate my point, is the fact that I could explain it to you, but you still would never get what I'm actually talking about. 

Isn't that an interesting point? You can change for people, you can take all the effort and do fake things like fake smiling at strangers (even though there's clear evidence that points not only can people tell the difference between a real smile and a fake/women find smiling men less attractive. But that's all besides the point) but ultimately, people make whatever assumptions they want. People's perceptions are based on whatever emotion they stew themselves in.

People in America smile, people in Soviet Blocs don't - they think it's fake and slimy. I could go on. The fact is people are judgemental and despite whatever you think life is about, I'm sitting here telling you- To Me, focusing on all this dumb shit for the rest of your entire life, running these circles, playing all these fake games? It's the same as the absurdity in the Victorian Era. It's all a waste of time. None of it is real. People would make assumptions about people without getting to know them, aren't great people! But it doesnt matter because life isn't about people, life is about us. You don't have to change who you are to fit in. You can be yourself, you can make it up as you go along.

 But again, it doesn't matter because I could still explain this all to you and you still wouldn't really know how much more free you are doing it my way. And that's okay, different strokes for different folks. I'm just here telling Reddit there's more than one way to play life.

I always follow up on plans even if I'm not planning on going. Whenever possible I let people have a for-sure answer whether we're doing something at a particular time/day/place. Nobody wants to keep a big question mark on their calendar hoping you make up your mind. If you say you're going, fucking go and go at the understood time.

I don't leave people on read if I have time to respond and I'm in anything above a truly bad headspace. It's about 50-50 on initiating conversations and plans but that wasn't always the case. I spent a lot of time initiating and following through on plans, so people are happy to invite me to parties and plans because I'm actually fun, I actually care, and I actually show up. 

At parties, I have a pretty good sense of who's there and doesn't want to be, who's there to get wasted, and who's looking to have a decent conversation and a lot of fun. I stick around the people who are there to have fun or at least open to it. I try to include everyone as much as possible but I'm not going to pry my way into someone's bubble who doesn't want to join the party. This is doubly true for people who've very clearly decided before arriving that they aren't going to enjoy themselves. 

The main thing I can recommend is practice and persistence until it becomes natural. Be kind to yourself in your choice of friends and be the kind of friend you want to have and model the kind of relationships you want to have.

Ok that's what I thought initially. Your friends almost sound like they operate on a "gang" dynamic, in that, once someone leaves or is banned from the group they become the enemy or a target for being picked on and bullied... and THIS is not what friends do! Something is very wrong with that, and it also sounds like these individuals could either be any combination of jocks, spoiled-ass rich kids or "Boyz from the Hood." On that note... let me tell you a little story about me.

I know middle school and even high school can be difficult, but I also recall that I had solved these problems by the time I became a senior in high school be carefully picking my friends and associates. My dear young friend let me tell you something... I am Black and I went to an all Black school in Jacksonville, FL many years ago and before they finally integrated the students and teachers. This school had students that came from three different housing projects and a few low-income areas on the westside of town. I had to fight my way through middle school just to keep my damn lunch money and stand up for myself when one of the high school bullies decided to try and punk me. I was that Black kid who just didn't fit it with a lot of kids because I did not care for all the ghetto crap or fighting. I also spoke a little differently in terms of my vernacular which attracted problems at times. LOL I liked a wide variety of music including R&B, soul, pop, rock and contemporary stuff which also translated to a variety of races on behalf of the artists that performed all of this music. I even chose a pop song to sing in my high school play, but I typically sang soul music on the talent shows. I can switch genres back and forth to this very day and think nothing of it. (I think it's very safe to say that most Black people are not into that.) I was an only child from a broken home being raised by a great-grandmother, and I was kind of different in my manner for reasons I was yet to fully understand until I became an adult. As for high school... hell I didn't even TRY to associate with people or groups that acted too "street, violent or ignorant." I just stayed the hell away from them because I knew I didn't really like them. However, I managed to get a little tougher to the point where the vast majority of this bunch would leave me alone as well because they could see it in my face that I didn't want to be bothered. I learned to stand up to them if provoked, and if someone pushed me too far then someone had a real fight on their hands. (People have a way of knowing who to mess with and who not to mess with... believe this.) I met up with a guy in a nightclub (or disco) who attended my high school several years after we'd all graduated. He came out and told me that he used to watch me in school and noticed the way I used to select my friends which really surprised me because he and I were never actual friends, and I didn't really think ANYONE paid attention to the few people I hung with except me! LOL Well he was right because I made it a point to only associate myself with kids who acted and carried themselves like regular well-mannered (or semi-well mannered) kids. They weren't "perfect" people and neither was I, but NONE of them were ignorant, ghetto, delinquent, violent or bullies. I didn't even try to date girls who acted like "hood girls" because I knew they represented one lane and I was driving in another. I found myself attracted to young ladies who ACTED like young ladies (and married one just like that). The bottom line is that I hate and literally despise ghetto mentality and behavior to this very day... and even moreso now because I know myself, and I have accepted who I really am as a person and an individual. If you want to say childhood and school experiences contributed to this strong dislike for ghetto behavior then you would not be wrong. lol 

Now back to you. I told you some of my personal story as a means of telling you that you are going to get a little tougher and "stand up for the person you really are inside." When you make the decision to do this then trust me... it will show on the outside because it will be genuine. You need to continue to speak your mind not only to this group and group leader you've told us about, but with "anyone" because practice is good. You should also "focus more on your future" in terms of your college major and the career you hope to have one day. Immerse yourself in people and activities that "make you smile" and focus more on the people you like instead of those whom you dislike. If you start to do more of these things, you will find that you won't even have TIME to deal with this troublesome group or any other type of nonsense to start with. Maybe it's just time to stop trying to fit-in where you no longer fit-in and move on. Just become too busy.  

I think I understand your feelings, concerns and need to separate yourself on a more gradual basis, and I respect them as well... so go ahead and do it gradually, but you can also do it more quickly if you make some changes in your own life and thinking. Start allowing yourself to experience and enjoy the company of other people whom you might have more in common with in terms of personality, interests understanding of the words "mutual respect." You need to move beyond this group of flakey and shakey individuals with a jerk for a ring leader because there's just something wrong with this group dynamic... and it really doesn't sound right for you because it's not who you are. You just seem to be more down-to-earth, intelligent that calm person who tolerates these people just to have friends, and people like you deserve better. 

Now here is where it gets really serious: If the spirit ever leads you to do so... you should pull the group leader away from the rest of the group or catch him or her alone one day and flat confront them about their behavior. It doesn't have to be angry... just be honest straight-forward, logical, vary rational but above all.. UNAFRAID. You will get better and more interesting results if you do this privately because if you try it in front of the group it could get ugly because you will have put this jerk on the spot and he/she will react in whatever way they deem necessary to hold power. lol If ever you decide to do this, you absolutely cannot be nervous, afraid or unsure of yourself in any way because he or she will sniff it out, sense it and try to pull a power play of some sort. You have to be ready for whatever no matter what and ready to deal with it. If it sounds like I'm saying you might even have to exchange a few punches that's exactly what I'm saying. Whatever you decide to do and however you decide to handle it... you have to stand up for yourself one way or another because you will encounter these type of people long after high school is over. I also want you to talk to your mom and dad or an older brother, sister, cousin or even a grand-parent about everything you've told me and see what they tell you as well. I will stop now, but I want you to have a great rest of your weekend and a good life. I've got a feeling great things are in store for you one day in your life, and everything you are experiencing and feeling now will help make it all come true.

Peace
